Yes, here are some additional tips and advice for a first-time Sakura grower:

1. Choose the right container: Make sure the container you choose is large enough to accommodate the plant's root system and allows for proper drainage. A good rule of thumb is to choose a container that is at least twice the size of the root ball of your plant.

2. Use the right soil: Sakura plants require well-draining soil that is rich in organic matter. Use a high-quality potting mix that contains 30% perlite or vermiculite to ensure adequate drainage.

3. Water consistently: Sakura plants require consistent moisture, so make sure to water them regularly. Stick your finger into the soil to determine if it's time to water. If the soil feels dry to the touch, it's time to water.

4. Don't over-fertilize: Over-fertilizing can damage your Sakura plant, so it's important to follow the instructions on the fertilizer package and avoid overfeeding.

5. Monitor for pests and diseases: Keep an eye on your plant for signs of pests or diseases, such as aphids or powdery mildew. Inspect your plant regularly and treat it immediately if you notice any issues.

6. Prune regularly: Regular pruning can help promote healthy growth and shape your Sakura plant. Prune at the appropriate time of year to avoid damaging your plant.

7. Have patience: Sakura plants can take a few years to mature and produce abundant blooms, so it's important to have patience and enjoy the process of growing your own beautiful Sakura tree.

I hope these tips help, and I wish you the best of luck in growing your Sakura plant on your balcony!
